STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 10, 2025
Jennifer LYNN Shores
SAGINAW COUNTY DHHS
411 E GENESEE AVE,
SAGINAW, MI, 48607-1254
Re: License #: CP730201395
SI #: 2025SIC0000330
Dear Jennifer LYNN Shores:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000330

License #: CP730201395
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Chief Administrator: Jennifer LYNN Shores
Agency Name: SAGINAW COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 411 E GENESEE AVE
SAGINAW, MI 48607-1254
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/07/2026

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
Description suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 1/23/25, foster care was monitoring a visit transfer between
parents and the youth playfully threw snow at the foster care
worker. The foster care worker made an inappropriate statement
and appeared angry making both parents uncomfortable.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Parent A was interviewed by phone on 1/29/2025. She requested
Advanced In-Home Worker be present as a support person. She
stated she and Youth A’s father live together; however, their
parenting time is court ordered to take place separately. She
stated on 1/23/2025, Parent B’s parenting time was supposed to
take place from 12:00-4:00pm. Foster Care Worker texted just
before 11:30am stating he was close to the home with Youth A, so
Parent A had to quickly leave the home. When Parent A walked
out of the home, Foster Care Worker and Youth A were already
there. Foster Care Worker told Youth A he could give Parent A a
hug before she left, so Parent A hugged him. She stated she and
Youth A threw a couple snowballs at one another then Parent A
told Youth A she had to leave. Parent A stated she didn’t see
anything, but she heard Foster Care Worker say, "you are lucky
you’re not my kid; I would kill you.” She stated Foster Care Worker
sounded angry when he made the statement. Parent A then got
into Advanced In-Home Worker’s car and Advanced In-Home
Worker asked Parent A how she felt about Foster Care Worker’s
comment. She stated the comment made her uncomfortable.
Advanced In-Home Worker was interviewed by phone on
1/29/2025. She reported she arrived to pick up Parent A to bring
her to the laundromat at approximately 11:25am. Advanced In-
Home Worker stated she also had her intern in her car. Foster
Care Worker arrived shortly after with Youth A. Advanced In-
Home Worker was in her car with her window down and said
“wow, you’re here early” to Foster Care Worker. Advanced In-
Home Worker stated Youth A’s parents aren’t supposed to be
2

home during each other’s parenting times and Foster Care Worker
knows he’s not supposed to be there that early. Advanced In-
Home Worker saw Parent A and Youth A throw snowballs at one
another and saw Youth A throw snow at Foster Care Worker. The
snow hit Foster Care Worker’s neck after which Foster Care
Worker angrily stated, “you are lucky you are not my kid, or I
would kill you.” Advanced In-Home Worker stated Foster Care
Worker looked at her when he made the comment, so she knows
he knows she heard him. Advanced In-Home Worker added that
Foster Care Worker has a history of saying things like this in the
past resulting in him being put on leave. She also added Foster
Care Worker has since been assigned only one case, at which
point the conversation was redirected as Parent A and Parent B
were present.
Parent B was interviewed by phone on 1/29/2025 and 2/6/2025.
He reported he was on the sidewalk and saw Youth A grab snow
and toss it at Foster Care Worker in a playful manner. He heard
Foster Care Worker say, “you’re lucky you’re not my kid” but didn’t
hear what was said after that as his focus was on how angry
Foster Care Worker was. Parent B stated he was more concerned
with Foster Care Worker’s angry demeanor than the statement
made. Parent B stated Youth A immediately apologized to Foster
Care Worker.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
1/20/2025. He reported he is primarily a monitor for PAFC cases
but has Youth A’s case assigned to him. He stated he picks Youth
A up from school on Tuesdays and Thursday around 2:30pm then
picks up Youth A’s sibling from that youth’s caregiver and arrives
at Parent A and Parent B’s home for parenting time. Both parents
have unsupervised parenting time. Foster Care Worker stated
parenting times takes place separately and the parents are not to
contact one another during the parenting times. He stated they are
allowed to see and speak to one another during transition, but
they are supposed to parent individually during parenting times, so
their ability to parent without the other parent present can be
assessed. On 1/23/2025, Parent B was supposed to have
parenting time from 12:00-4:00PM then Parent A 4:00-8:00PM.
Foster Care Worker stated he was told Youth A was dismissed
from school at 11:30AM that day, but he was released earlier than
that, so he arrived at Parent A and Parent B’s home early. He
stated Parent A was still home and Advanced In-Home Worker
was there to pick up Parent A. He stated Youth A gave Parent A a
hug before Parent A got into Advanced In-Home Worker’s car.
Youth A threw snow at Foster Care Worker, and it hit the side of
3

his face and ran down into his shirt. Foster Care Worker stated he
took a deep breath and closed his eyes. After he opened his eyes,
he saw Youth A smirking. Foster Care Worker said, “ dude, if you
were my kid, your face would be in the snow.” Foster Care Worker
stated Advanced In-Home Worker and an intern were in Advanced
In-Home Worker’s car with the window down and Parent A and
Parent B were present, so they likely all heard his comment.
Foster Care Worker stated he then said, “don’t worry, dad will get
you back” after which Parent B threw snow at Youth A and said, “I
got him.” Foster Care Worker denied ever saying he would kill
Youth A and added he would never say that to a foster youth. He
stated he was attempting to hold his composer to the best of his
ability after being hit with the snow as this was not the first time
Youth A has pushed Foster Care Worker’s personal boundaries.
Foster Care Worker stated neither of the parents have mentioned
anything to him about his comment.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 was interviewed via video
conferencing on 1/30/2025. She stated she received an email
from an Adoption Option, Inc Supervisor on 1/24/2205 indicating
Foster Care Worker stated “you are lucky you are not my child, or
I would kill you” to Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated the
family used to have an in-home worker through Adoption Option,
Inc but there is no longer a worker assigned; however, she
believes the worker still provides support to the family. Foster
Care Supervisor 1 stated she met with Foster Care Worker the
following Monday and told him what the email said. He told Foster
Care Supervisor 1 he stated something along the lines of, if you
were my kid I would get you and your dad is going to get you.
Foster Care Supervisor 1 stated when Foster Care Worker
relayed this to her, he did not sound angry or upset. She reported
Foster Care Worker has one direct care case assigned to him
because he is primarily a monitor, so she does not have a lot of
opportunity to see him interact with youth and families. She stated
she became his supervisor fairly recently and she has had no
concerns with his performance; however, he is currently under
some type of performance plan, but his former supervisor would
have more information about those specifics.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 was interviewed via video
conferencing on 1/30/2025. She stated she was previously the
assigned Foster Care Worker for Youth A’s case. When Foster
Care Worker came under her as a supervisor, the case was
assigned to Foster Care Worker as she was familiar with the case.
She stated there was an investigation approximately 2 years ago
into an inappropriate comment Foster Care Worker made. Foster
4

Care Worker had a one-day suspension and has since done a lot
of work on boundaries. Foster Care Supervisor 2 stated Foster
Care Worker’s personality is “overly jokey”, and he is a “no filter
kind of guy.” She stated he demonstrated an increased awareness
of boundaries and there have been no issues with him saying
anything inappropriate in the past 2 years. She stated if he made
the alleged comment, he would not have had any malice behind it.
She added he is trying to be as appropriate as he can.
Adoption Option Inc Intern was interviewed by phone on
1/30/2025. She stated she was in the passenger seat of Advanced
In-Home Worker’s car at Parent A’s home on 1/23/2024. She
stated they were parked in front of Parent A’s home when Foster
Care Worker told Youth A he could give Parent A a hug. Adoption
Option Inc Intern heard Parent A make a joke about a snowball
fight with Youth A after which they threw some snowballs back
and forth. Parent A then hugged Youth A, said goodbye, and
walked toward Advanced In-Home Worker’s car. Youth A then
threw some snow at Foster Care Worker’s face. Foster Care
Worker seemed upset, but then turned and said, “if you were my
child, you would be dead.” Adoption Option Inc Intern stated she
doesn’t think Parent A heard Foster Care Worker say that and
they did not talk about it in the car.
Youth A was interviewed by phone on 2/6/2025. He stated he
remembered throwing snow at Foster Care Worker after which
Foster Care Worker said, “if you were my kid, I would put your
face in the snow.”
Analysis A violation is established as Foster Care Worker did not
demonstrate responsible character when making a comment to
Youth A about either killing Youth A or putting Youth A’s face in
the snow after Youth A threw snow at him.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
February 6, 2025
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 7, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
6
